tn.text: Yahweh speaks to Ezekiel.
"Yahweh spoke his word." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:01|1:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
AT: "in the ninth year of the exile of King Jehoiachin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: the tenth month, and on the tenth day of the month
tn.text: "the tenth day of the tenth month." This is the tenth month of the Hebrew calendar. The tenth day is near the beginning of January on Western calendars. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_hebrewmonths]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])

tn.ref: the king of Babylon has besieged Jerusalem
tn.text: The army of Babylon is referred to by its leader. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: heap up the bones under it
tn.text: Some cultures add bones to a fire because they burn longer than wood. AT: "place the rest of the bones under the pot to fuel the fire"
Yahweh compares Jerusalem to a cooking pot. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
the red material that forms on metal. Rust eats away at metal and eventually destroys it
Yahweh does not give this command to a specific person, instead he is commanding some imaginary person who is part of the metaphor.

tn.ref: but do not cast lots for it
tn.text: Casting lots was a way of choosing which pieces of meat to take out, but because Yahweh wants to take out all of the pieces of meat, there is no need to cast lots.
Yahweh continues giving Ezekiel his message to the people of Jerusalem.
The word "her" refers to Jerusalem, which is represented by the cooking pot.

tn.ref: has set it on the smooth rock
tn.text: "has put the blood on bare rocks"
"and cover it with dirt"
Yahweh continues to compare Jerusalem with a cooking pot.

tn.ref: I will also enlarge the pile of wood
tn.text: It is implied that the pile of wood is under the cooking pot, which represents Jerusalem. "I will make the pile of wood on the fire under you even bigger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Stack up ... kindle ... Cook ... let the bones be charred
tn.text: Yahweh gives these commands to imaginary people who are part of the metaphor.
"burn the bones." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
to burn the surface of something.
when something causes metal to break apart and rust.
"burnt away"
AT: "Jerusalem has become tired"
difficult labor.
Yahweh continues to speak to Jerusalem by comparing it to a cooking pot.

tn.ref: your activities, they will judge you
tn.text: what they have done proves they are guilty of sin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: this is the Lord Yahweh's declaration
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:05:11|5:11]].
"Yahweh spoke his word." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:01|1:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to Ezekiel's wife. Yahweh refers to Ezekiel by the part of his body he uses to see his wife. (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]]).

tn.ref: you must not mourn nor weep, and your tears must not flow
tn.text: These phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Ezekiel is not to cry about his wife dying. AT: "you must not express your grief." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
a head covering made of a long cloth wrapped around the head.
a simple shoe held onto the foot with straps around the ankles.

tn.ref: do not veil your facial hair
tn.text: In Israel, men would shave their beards to express sorrow, then cover their faces until their facial hair grew back. Yahweh told Ezekiel to not cover his facial hair to show that he had not shaved his face to express his sorrow.
The people of Israel question Ezekiel and Ezekiel tells them what Yahweh has said to them.
"Yahweh spoke his word." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:01|1:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
AT: "pride in the building that you have made"
AT: "the building that you delight to look at" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
AT: "be killed in war" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here wasting away and dying is spoken of as melting. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This implies that God will not forgive the sins of these people. However, some modern versions translate "because of your iniquities."
the sound a person makes who wants help, but pain or sorrow is so strong that they are not capable of speaking.
someone who has been forced to leave their country because of war or another disaster.

tn.ref: your mouth will be opened up
tn.text: "Yahweh will open your mouth" This describes someone being given understanding and the ability to speak about something. AT: "you will know what to say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: you will speak—you will no longer be silent
tn.text: Both of these mean the people of Israel will speak. It is said again as a negative to emphasis the positive. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
This refers to the people of Israel as a sign because they will help the refugees to understand why Jerusalem was destroyed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
